title: How to Shave with Baby Oil

steps.title: Yes, you can use baby oil as a substitute for shaving cream.
steps.content: Yes, you can use baby oil as a substitute for shaving cream. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Mineral oil, the main ingredient in baby oil, doesn't get absorbed through the skin, making it totally okay for your shaving needs. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source In fact, baby oil can be a great moisturizer, especially if you have dry skin. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Feel free to use baby oil during your morning face shave! [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Just be sure to shave with your hair growth instead of against it—this way, you won't end up with any pesky razor bumps. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Baby oil can also work well for underarm shaving. Start by shaving in an upward direction, which trims away the bulk of the hair. Then, shave in a downward direction to clear away the root. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Plan to shave when you’re about finished with your bath or shower.
steps.content: Plan to shave when you’re about finished with your bath or shower. [7] X Expert Source Marlon Rivas Facial Hair Specialist Expert Interview. 17 January 2020. Ideally, give your legs at least 10 minutes to soak, which helps to soften up your skin. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Plus, a bath or shower gives you the chance to scrub away any dead skin cells from your legs, which can get stuck in your razor. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Rub baby oil over your skin.
steps.content: Rub baby oil over your skin. Shaving cream, baby oil, and any other shaving substitutes all have 1 job: to keep your skin nice and lubricated. [10] X Expert Source Marlon Rivas Facial Hair Specialist Expert Interview. 17 January 2020. The baby oil helps your razor stay really close to your skin, which leaves your legs with a silky-smooth finish. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Apply enough baby oil to completely cover your legs.

steps.title: Glide your razor along the grain of your leg hair.
steps.content: Glide your razor along the grain of your leg hair. Shaving against your hair growth can lead to uncomfortable razor burn and/or razor bumps. [12] X Expert Source Juan Sabino Professional Barber Expert Interview. 28 January 2020. To be on the safe side, replace your razor blade or disposable razor once every 5-7 shaving sessions. [13] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Yes, especially if you have dry skin.
steps.content: Yes, especially if you have dry skin. Experts recommend moisturizing your skin after hopping out of the bath or shower, before your skin completely dries. [14] X Expert Source Marlon Rivas Facial Hair Specialist Expert Interview. 17 January 2020. Blot away any extra water, and rub the baby oil all over your feet, hands, and legs, which helps lock the moisture inside. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You don’t need to apply baby oil on your face unless your skin is really dry. You can also use jojoba oil with a few drops of essential oils. Obviously, be careful with what you put in your skin, as you can have an allergic reaction to some oils. [16] X Expert Source Juan Sabino Professional Barber Expert Interview. 28 January 2020.

steps.title: Yes, you can.
steps.content: Yes, you can. Standard shaving cream is definitely the most popular, widely-accepted shaving solution, but experts agree that body oils (such as baby oil) are an acceptable replacement. Even hair conditioners can work in a pinch! [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Some people aren’t a fan of using baby oil down there since the product irritates their skin. To be safe, patch-test a tiny section of skin to make sure you don’t have any bad reactions.

steps.title: Shave carefully and cautiously to prevent any discomfort.
steps.content: Shave carefully and cautiously to prevent any discomfort. Start by trimming your pubic hair down with a sharp pair of scissors, so it’s easier to get a closer, more comfortable shave. Take a few minutes to soak in the tub or shower, which helps soften the skin. Dry your skin gently and delicately rub some baby oil over the skin that you plan to shave. Tug your skin so it’s completely taut, and use your opposite hand to shave in upward strokes. Once you’re finished, rinse off the freshly-shaved skin with warm water. Shave in downward strokes if you tend to get razor bumps and/or ingrown hairs. Some people like to wait a few minutes after drying off, so their skin has a chance to breathe.

steps.title: Yes, you definitely can.
steps.content: Yes, you definitely can. In fact, coating your skin with baby oil may prevent pimples from popping up after the fact. Plus, baby oil makes your skin feel silky-smooth, even down there.

steps.title: No, it doesn’t, despite popular belief.
steps.content: No, it doesn’t, despite popular belief. Mineral oil is pretty controversial in the beauty and skincare community—some believe that it contributes to acne breakouts because of past animal testing. Still, modern research rooted in human testing suggests that mineral oil will not block up your pores. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Possibly, but using proper shaving techniques is your best bet.
steps.content: Possibly, but using proper shaving techniques is your best bet. Try to shave with the grain of your hair, removing as much hair as you can with each stroke of the razor. Once you’re finished shaving, rinse off your skin with some cool water. [19] X Research source If you use an electric razor, double-check that it isn’t programmed to the closest setting. This could reduce your risk of developing razor bumps.

steps.title: Coconut oil is a possibility.
steps.content: Coconut oil is a possibility. This oil has both anti-bacterial and anti-fungal properties and is very hydrating for your skin. The next time you hop in the shower, slather some coconut oil over your skin before reaching for the razor. [20] X Research source Don’t use coconut oil as a shaving cream substitute if you struggle with acne.

steps.title: Olive oil can be a good option.
steps.content: Olive oil can be a good option. [21] X Expert Source Marlon Rivas Facial Hair Specialist Expert Interview. 17 January 2020. This oil keeps your skin nice and lubricated, and even prevents unpleasant razor bumps and razor burn from popping up after the fact. Before your next shaving session, stop by your kitchen to pick up this worthwhile shaving cream replacement. [22] X Research source
